description: Borrowed from French cadet, from Gascon capdet, from Late Latin capitellum (“small head”). Attested in English from 1634.
Doublet of caddy, caudillo, and capitellum.

entries.meaning: A student at a military school who is training to be an officer.
(largely historical) A younger or youngest son, who would not inherit as a firstborn son would.
(in compounds, chiefly in genealogy) Junior. (See also the heraldic term cadency.)
examples: a cadet branch of the family

entries.meaning: (archaic, US, slang) A young man who makes a business of ruining girls to put them in brothels.
(New Zealand, historical) A young gentleman learning sheep farming at a station; also, any young man attached to a sheep station.
